October 7, 1984: Fiction
THE FOURTH PROTOCOL, by Frederick Forsyth. (Viking, $17.95.) A London
jewel robbery leads to plots and counterplots behind the Iron Curtain.
''. . . AND LADIES OF THE CLUB,'' by Helen Hooven Santmyer. (Putnam,
$19.95.) Life in an Ohio town, 1868 to 1932.
FIRST AMONG EQUALS, by Jeffrey Archer. (Linden Press/Simon & Schuster,
$16.95.) Three young men vie to be chosen Prime Minister of Britain.
LINCOLN, by Gore Vidal. (Random House, $19.95.) Fictionalized account of the
Civil War Presidency.
TOUGH GUYS DON'T DANCE, by Norman Mailer. (Random House, $16.95.) A
murder mystery set in Provincetown, Mass.
CRESCENT CITY, by Belva Plain. (Delacorte, $16.95.) Life in 19th-century New
Orleans, seen from the viewpoint of a Jewish woman.
STRONG MEDICINE, by Arthur Hailey. (Doubleday, $16.95.) A strong woman
rises in the pharmaceutical industry.
JOB: A Comedy of Justice, by Robert A. Heinlein. (Del Rey, $16.95.) A bigoted yet
lovable religious man has his faith tested in a series of tribulations in a variety of
alternate worlds.
THE MIKO, by Eric Van Lustbader. (Villard Books, $16.95.) An American
businessman struggles with a vengeful Japanese sorceress in a high-stakes battle
involving oil.
GOD KNOWS, by Joseph Heller. (Knopf, $16.95.) King David tells his story in
comic and irreverent style.
THE BUTTER BATTLE BOOK, by Dr. Seuss. (Random House, $6.95.) A warning
about the nuclear arms race in words and pictures.
THE AQUITAINE PROGRESSION, by Robert Ludlum. (Random House, $17.95.)
A lawyer is caught in a conspiracy to seize the Western world.
THE OUTSIDER, by Howard Fast. (Houghton Mifflin, $15.95.) Life in a small New
England town as seen by a young rabbi and his family.
ROLE OF HONOR, by John Gardner. (Putnam, $11.95.) James Bond leaves
Government service to become a private spy.
FULL CIRCLE, by Danielle Steel. (Delacorte, $16.95.) The relationship of a
mother and daughter is altered by the changing values of the past 40 years.
October 7, 1984
Non-Fiction
LOVING EACH OTHER, by Leo Buscaglia. (Slack/Holt, Rinehart & Winston,
$13.95.) Suggestions for ''setting our priorities right in order to enjoy life to the
fullest.''
THE BRIDGE ACROSS FOREVER, by Richard Bach. (Morrow, $16.95.) The
author of ''Jonathan Livingston Seagull'' recounts his search for a true love.
PIECES OF MY MIND, by Andrew A. Rooney. (Atheneum, $12.95.) More essays
by the journalist and television commentator.
THE KENNEDYS: An American Drama, by Peter Collier and David Horowitz.
(Summit, $20.95.) The dark as well as the glamorous sides of four generations of
a prominent family.
THE REST OF US, by Stephen Birmingham. (Little, Brown, $19.95.) Success
stories of American Jews from Eastern Europe.
HEY, WAIT A MINUTE, I WROTE A BOOK! by John Madden with Dave
Anderson. (Villard Books, $14.95.) An anecdotal autobiography of the popular
television sports announcer.
IN GOD'S NAME, by David A. Yallop. (Bantam, $16.95.) A British journalist argues
that Pope John Paul I's death in 1978 was a case of murder.
WIRED, by Bob Woodward. (Simon & Schuster, $17.95.) The troubled life of the
late entertainer John Belushi.
THE WENDY DILEMMA , by Dan Kiley. (Arbor House, $25.95.) Why some women
inappropriately mother their men.
THE NIGHTMARE YEARS: 1930-1940, by William L. Shirer. (Little, Brown,
$22.50.) Second volume of the memoirs of a celebrated foreign correspondent.
GOOD MORNING, MERRY SUNSHINE, by Bob Greene. (Atheneum, $14.95.)
The syndicated columnist's journal of his child's first year.
A LIGHT IN THE ATTIC, by Shel Silverstein. (Harper & Row, $13.50.) Light verse
and drawings by the author.
ONE WRITER'S BEGINNINGS, by Eudora Welty. (Harvard, $10.) The novelist
recalls her childhood in Mississippi.
MEN: An Owner's Manual, by Stephanie Brush. (Linden Press/Simon & Schuster,
$11.95.) Advice to women about handling the male of the species; satire.
CLOSE ENCOUNTERS, by Mike Wallace and Gary Paul Gates. (Morrow,
$17.95.) A memoir by the ''60 Minutes'' reporter.
